title-group.article-title: Does elevating silver content in zinc-based glass polyalkenoate cements increase their antibacterial efficacy against two common bacteria using the agar gel diffusion method?

article-meta.aff: 1Inamori School of Engineering, Alfred University, Alfred, NY, USA
2College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, Alfred University, Alfred, NY, USA
3Material Surface Science Institute, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland

author-notes.corresp: A Coughlan, Inamori School of Engineering, Alfred University, Alfred, NY 14802, USA. Email: Coughlan@alfred.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The authors have previously shown that it is possible to incorporate silver into a soda-zinc-silicate glass and subsequently form a glass polyalkenoate cement from it. The objective of the research described herein is to determine if incremental increases in the silver content of these glass polyalkenoate cements will increase their antibacterial efficacy against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria using the accepted spread plate method. Four glass polyalkenoate cements were formulated; three contained increasing amounts of silver incorporated into them (cements A, B, and C, containing 0.33 mol%, 0.66 mol%, and 0.99 mol% silver, respectively) and a fourth contained no silver, which acted as a control (control cement). The handling properties of the glass polyalkenoate cements were evaluated, where working times were around 2 min and setting times ranged from 1 h 17 min to 2 h 41 min. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy was employed to determine silver ion release with cement maturation for up to 14 days. The majority of silver ions were released within the first 24 h, with up to 2 mg/L cumulative ion release recorded up to 14 days. The antibacterial properties of the coatings were evaluated against Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria. The silver-glass polyalkenoate cements exhibited antibacterial effect against both bacterial strains. The maximum inhibition zones recorded against S. aureus was 14.8 mm (SD ± 1.11) and against P. aeruginosa was 20.6 mm (SD ± 0.81). Cement B had a greater antibacterial effect compared to cement A, however, cements B and C had comparable antibacterial effects after 14 days even though cement C contained 0.33 mol% more silver than B. This indicates that by increasing the silver content in these cements, the antibacterial efficacy increases to a point, but there is a threshold where further silver ion release does not increase the antibacterial effect.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bone cements should have the ability to bond to both bone and surgical metals, exhibit no chemical or thermal necrosis, and have no significant shrinkage or exotherm upon setting. Taking these properties into consideration, glass polyalkenoate cements (GPCs) have potential as bone cements. The GPCs are formed by the reaction between an ion-leachable glass and an aqueous solution of polyacrylic acid (PAA)1 and have proven antibacterial and cariostatic2 properties, which are related to their ability to release beneficial amounts of ions over time.3,4 The GPCs can be formulated to release ions that can have a therapeutic benefit in a chosen application such as fluoride release in dental applications,5 which assists in the prevention of secondary caries.6 A recurring problem with all commercial GPCs is that they contain aluminum (Al), a known neurotoxin.7,8 The presence of Al can retard surgical applications as aluminum ion (Al3+) release in vivo has been reported to cause demineralization of bone tissue.9,10 Recently, GPCs have been formulated with zinc (Zn) replacing Al;2,11–21 a more biologically acceptable ion.22

The authors have previously shown that GPCs based on a glass phase containing both Zn and silver (Ag) have the ability to release ions which are antibacterial against both Staphylococcus aureus (Oxford strain)19 and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (a clinical isolate)20,23 in vitro and methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) both in vitro11 and in vivo.11 Bacteria differ in their shape, size and structure, in their chemical activities, in the type of nutrients they need, in the form of energy they use, and in the physical conditions under which they can grow.24 S. aureus is a prevalent pathogen in prosthetic joint infection and it is also a leading cause of cardiothoracic sternotomy site infections, often with bone osteomyelitis. The authors have also shown that their cements have the ability to inhibit proliferation of a biofilm of P. aeruginosa (PA01).23 P. aeruginosa is a common cause of hospital-acquired infection.25 Most of these infections are endemic. It causes a wide variety of hospital-acquired infections including those associated with urinary tract catheters and chronic osteomyelitis.26 It is a common cause of nosocomial pneumonia, burn, and wound infection.27 Also, in the United States, P. aeruginosa ranked first among all nosocomial pathogens related to pneumonia in intensive care units reported to the National Nosocomial Infection Surveillance System.28

Studies have shown that inhibition of bacterial growth correlates with zinc (Zn2+) and silver (Ag+) ion release from novel GPCs.11,19 The Zn2+ has been shown to inhibit multiple activities in the bacterial cell including glycolysis, transmembrane protein translocation, and acid tolerance.16 It also influences pH, which rises throughout glycolysis via the action of Zn2+ on the bacterial cell wall and therefore leaves an excess of OH– that results in a favorable bioactive response.29 The minimum Zn2+ concentration required for P. aeruginosa inhibition is 6.02 × 10−4 µg/mL30 and 3.10−2 µg/mL for S. aureus.31 The Ag is regarded as one of the noble metals with high biocompatibility.32 The Ag+ is also a known antibacterial agent.33,34 The Ag nanoparticles are also known to have antimicrobial properties.32 Bone cements loaded with 1% of nano-Ag revealed high antibacterial activity against many strains of bacteria.35 To have antimicrobial efficacy against P. aeruginosa bacteria, Ag+ must be released in biocidal concentrations of 1.102 × 10−6 µg/mL36 and 7.94 µg/mL for S. aureus.37 The Ag+ avidly binds to negatively charged components in proteins and nucleic acids, thereby causing structural changes in bacterial cell walls, membranes, and nucleic acids that affect viability.38 The authors have also reported that greater amounts of Zn2+ are released from GPCs when the glass phase also contains Ag.19

The objective of the study reported herein is to build on the authors previous publications in order to determine if increases in Ag content of the glass phase of these cements will result in a concomitant increase in antibacterial efficacy of the resultant Ag–Zn GPCs formulated from them.

sec.title: Glass synthesis
sec.p:
Four glass compositions were produced (Table 1), a control (Control) and three glasses with increasing silver oxide (Ag2O) content at the expense of zinc oxide (ZnO; A, B, and C). Table 1.
Glass compositions (mol. fraction).
Glass SiO2 ZnO Na2O Ag2O
Control 56.04 33.09 10.87 0.00
A 56.04 32.76 10.87 0.33
B 56.04 32.43 10.87 0.66
C 56.04 32.10 10.87 0.99
SiO2: silicon dioxide, ZnO: zinc oxide, Na2O: sodium oxide, Ag2O: silver oxide.

Glasses were fired in a platinum (Pt) crucible (1450°C, 1 h) and then quenched in water. After quenching, the frit was dried (1 h, 100°C) in an oven. The glass was ground in a gyromill in 10 s increments. The glass powder was then passed through a 25 µm sieve.

sec.title: Polyacrylic acid
sec.p: Ciba specialty polymers (Bradford, United Kingdom) supplied the PAA, which was coded E9 (Mw = 80,800) in aqueous solution (25 vol%). The PAA was subsequently freeze-dried and ground (maximum particle size, 90 µm).

sec.title: X-ray diffraction
sec.p: Diffraction patterns for all glasses were collected using a Philips PW 1800 X-ray diffractometer (Philips, Netherlands). Each sample was placed on a zero background plate. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed from 10° < 2θ < 80° at a step of 0.05, and a count of 4. A voltage of 40 kV, and a current of 35 mA were used, utilizing Cu Kα radiation.

sec.title: Differential thermal analysis
sec.p: Differential thermal analysis (DTA; SDT 2960 Simultaneous DSC-TGA, New Castle, DE) was performed to evaluate the glass transition temperature (Tg) for each glass. A heating rate of 10°C/min was used in an oxygen atmosphere up to a maximum temperature of 700°C, using a platinum pan with an equivalent weighted alumina reference.

sec.title: Network connectivity
sec.p: The network connectivity (NC) for each glass was found using Equation (1). (1)NC=No.BO ' s-No.NBOsTotal No.Briding species
BO = bridging oxygens.
NBO = Nonbridging oxygens.

sec.title: Particle size analysis
sec.p: Particle size analysis (PSA) of the glasses were undertaken (Beckman Coulter Multisizer 4, Brea, CA). Samples were tested in a solution of sodium chloride and spun continuously with a glass stirrer to ensure even particle distribution, where 30,000 counts were taken through a 100 µm filters.

sec.title: Cement preparation
sec.p: A total of 0.5 g of each glass was mixed with 0.3 g of E9 PAA and water (∼0.4 mL) on a clean flat glass plate using a stainless steel spatula to produce a series of cements with consistent handling properties.

sec.title: Working time and setting time
sec.p:
Working times (Wt) of the cements were evaluated by measuring time from the addition of deionized water to the premixed PAA and glass components to where the cement was no longer pliable, and self-adherence was observed. Setting times (St) were evaluated according to ISO 9917.39 An Al mold (Figure 1) was used to hold setting samples for measuring St; Al foil was employed as a backing for the mold. The dimensions of the mould were: 10 mm × 8 mm × 5 mm. The mold was filled with mixed cement and immediately placed in a 37°C oven. A Vicat needle indenter was used to measure St by lowering a mass (400 g) onto the cement surface for 5 s; the indentation response of the GPC was recorded. Measurements were taken every 60 s until the needle failed to indent the cement surface. A set of three St measurements per cement composition were recorded. Figure 1.
Mould used to determine setting time of glass polyalkenoate cement (GPC).

sec.title: Ion release
sec.p: The Ag+ release of the GPCs were measured at 1, 7, and 14 days using Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-AES; Perkin Elmer Optima 3000 DV) using a Ag standard reference, and sample size, n = 3. Ion release testing was conducted using deionized water. The GPC discs were formed in silicon moulds (8 mm Ø, 2 mm th) for ion release testing. The moulds were filled with cement, positioned between acetate sheets and clamped with Al plates and placed in an oven (37°C, 24 h). The surface area of each disc was calculated. The constructs were matured in analytical water; with up to 65 mL of water immersing the samples. The amount of water was calculated using Equation (2). (2)rS=SA10
rS = rate of solution.
SA = surface area.

sec.title: Antibacterial testing
sec.p: S. aureus (ATCC 12600) and P. aeruginosa (ATCC 10145) were used for all antibacterial challenge tests. Brain heart infusion agar (BHI Agar, Difco, Detroit, MI) was prepared for all bacterial growth, with a fixed volume of 25 mL media per plate. Bacterial stocks were maintained at −80°C in BHI plus 25% glycerol. Bacterial cultures were plated and subcultured at least twice before fresh plates were prepared for antibacterial testing. Suspensions of bacteria for antibacterial testing were prepared from plates grown for less than 18 h. Bacteria were suspended in sterile phosphate buffered saline solution (PBS) to a density of approximately 107 colony forming units (CFU)/mL. The bacterial concentration was determined by a spectrophotometer (Genesys 10-S, WI). All plates were cultured in a Thermo Forma Series incubator under standard atmospheric gas concentrations, and did not demonstrate any evidence of drying over the 14-day experimental period.

The GPC discs formed using silicon moulds as described in Section Ion release were used directly in single disk diffusion assays40 and as performed previously.19 A bacterial suspension was prepared as described above, 200 µL of the suspension was spread on an agar plate, and a set disc was placed at the center of the plate. Plates were allowed to sit at room temperature until the suspension was completely absorbed into the agar and then placed agar side up in the incubator. The diameter of the zone of inhibition for each disk was measured and recorded at 1, 7, and 14 days. The zone of inhibition was calculated by averaging five independent measurements for each disk, and at least three disks were averaged to calculate the zone of inhibition for each cement.

sec.title: Characterization of glass
sec.p:
The XRD was performed on the four glasses, to confirm that each material was amorphous. The DTA confirmed that the Tgs of all four glasses were similar (569–576°C; Table 2). The NC was calculated at 2.43 for each glass. The glasses were all formulated from <25 µm particles. Table 2.
Glass transition temperatures (Tg) of the four glasses.
Glass Tg (°C)
Control 571
A 570
B 569
C 576

sec.title: Cement characterization
sec.p:
The Wt and St were evaluated for the four GPCs and are compiled in Tables 3 and 4. Table 3.
Average working times (Wt) for four cements (n = 3) using E9 polyacrylic acid (PAA).
Trial Time
Control 2 min 05 s
A 1 min 59 s
B 2 min 15 s
C 2 min 01 s
Table 4.
Average setting times (St) for four cements (n = 3) using E9 polyacrylic acid (PAA).
Trial Time
Control 2 h 27 min
A 2 h 0 min
B 1 h 17 min
C 2 h 41 min

The Wt of the cements facilitated the deployment of a uniform coating on the metal discs. Regarding the long Sts of the cements compared to those of conventional GPCs,13,15 these are likely to be a result of the high molecular weight PAA (E9, Mw = 80,800) employed. The extended chain lengths of the PAA in the same volume of water used in the mixing regimes highlighted in the literature may result in compromised hydrolysis leading to incomplete uncoiling of the chains retarding entanglement and formation of partially covalent bonds41 between the Zn2+ and the carboxylate groups.

sec.title: Ion release evaluation
sec.p:
The ion release profiles of Ag can be observed in Figure 2, where the dotted lines indicate the Ag concentrations in the three cements (excluding the control). As expected, the majority of the Ag+ release from the cements occurred in the first 24 h but Ag+ is recorded as being released for up to 14 days upon which testing was halted. Cement A releases the least amount of Ag+ (0.737 ± 0.018 mg/L) with C releasing the most (2.068 ± 0.004 mg/L). This is in-line with the Ag content of the glasses that have been used to make these cements (Table 1). The control cement did not release Ag, when evaluated under ICP, as was expected. Figure 2.
Graph shows cumulative ion release profiles of silver ion (Ag+) from glass polyalkenoate cements (GPCs). The silver (Ag) content in the glass polyalkenoate cement (GPC) series is indicated using dotted lines. The table below details the raw data for the chart.

sec.title: Antibacterial testing
sec.p:
The antibacterial efficacy of each GPC against two different bacterial species, gram-positive S. aureus and gram negative P. aeruginosa, were evaluated. The Ag-containing GPCs did not show notably increased inhibition of growth of S. aureus compared to the control cement (Figure 3), while there appeared to be a dose-dependent inhibition of growth of P. aeruginosa (Figures 4 and 5). The pH can be ruled out as a possible cause for the antibacterial effect as the pH ranged from 6.2 to 7.0 in all solutions at all time frames. Figure 3.
Antibacterial testing of four glasses of varying silver (Ag) content against Staphylococcus aureus (gram positive).
Figure 4.
Antibacterial testing of four glasses of varying silver (Ag) content against Pseudomonas aeruginosa (gram negative).
Figure 5.
Ion release vs zone of inhibition.

This differential response between the two bacterial species to the cements is not unexpected, given that the concentration of Ag+ necessary for inhibition of gram-negative bacteria (1.102 × 10–6 µg/mL)36 is six logs lower than the concentration needed to inhibit gram-positive organisms (0.125 µg/mL).42 The large zones of inhibition present in the S. aureus control (Figure 3) is likely to be due to the antibacterial activity of Zn2+, which was present in all samples, and is known to have antimicrobial activity.2

The P. aeruginosa zones of inhibition reduced over 14 days (Figure 4). This is likely to be due to the Ag+ release having a bacteriostatic effect on the outer edge of the zone, combined with the decreasing concentration of Ag+ in the media as one moves away from the cement disk. It is important to note that at no time did P. aeruginosa demonstrate the ability to grow in the immediate proximity (7 mm) of the cement disk (Figure 4). This suggests that all three concentrations of Ag used as additives in this experiment generated a concentration of Ag+ in the media, which completely inhibited P. aeruginosa growth in proximity of the cement disks themselves.

Figure 5 shows that cements B and C result in the same size inhibition zones after 14 days. Considering that there was a greater ion release of Ag from cement C compared to B, there would be expected to be a greater inhibition zone for C. As this is not the case, this indicates that there is a maximum inhibitory concentration (MIC) for Ag+ against both S. aureus and P. aeruginosa. Further testing will be required to evaluate the precise MIC.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The GPCs can be formulated to release antibacterial ions. The objective of this work was to determine the feasibility of adding increasing amounts of Ag into a series of novel GPCs and testing the resultant antibacterial efficacy using an accepted in vitro methodology for the potential of developing an Ag–GPC bone cement. This research has shown that adding more Ag to the glass phase of a GPC allows more Ag+ to be released. However, increasing the Ag content in the GPCs does not automatically increase antibacterial efficacy. This indicates the possibility of a MIC. Further research is required to identify the exact MIC of Ag in a GPC.

sec.title: Limitations of Study
sec.p: The authors acknowledge that bacterial adhesion on the surface will be influenced by protein absorbance on the bacterial surface43 but this is a preliminary laboratory-based study and as such, it is accepted that agar gel diffusion assay is an accepted methodology for in vitro testing.
